elements.content: Heterogeneous Electro-Fenton (EF) enables rapid elimination of recalcitrant organic pollutants without producing undesirable byproducts, but stable functioning of this process remains challenging. In this work, a porous composite of ferric oxide/nitrogen/carbon (Fe2O3/N–C) with good EF activity and stability was fabricated from iron-based metal–organic framework compounds (MOFs) and polyaniline via one-step pyrolysis. The incorporated Fe2O3 nanocrystals and the pyridinic and pyrrolic-N species endow the material with high catalytic activity for hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) generation and activation. The efficient degradation of bisphenol A and several other organic pollutants, dominated by a heterogeneous EF pathway, was achieved in acidic solution. The catalyst had low Fe leaching (0.52 mg/L after 2 h of reaction) and retained 98% of its original activity after four cycles of repeated use. Therefore, Fe2O3/N–C may serve as an efficient, stable, and environmentally benign heterogeneous EF catalyst for wastewater treatment and environmental remediation applications.

The efficient degradation of bisphenol A and several other organic pollutants, dominated by a heterogeneous EF pathway, was achieved in acidic solution. The catalyst had low Fe leaching (0.52 mg/L after 2 h of reaction) and retained 98% of its original activity after four cycles of repeated use. elements.content: Electro-Fenton (EF) technologies have been increasingly used for organic pollutant degradation due to their high efficiency and environmental benignity relative to many other advanced oxidation processes. In the EF process, H2O2 and ferrous ions (Fe2+) are electrochemically generated in a controlled manner to yield hydroxyl radicals (HO•), and the process can be readily integrated with photocatalytic processes for sustainable operation. Of particular interest are the heterogeneous EF processes, which allow catalyst recycling and minimize the production of iron sludge wastes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Electro-Fenton (EF) technologies have been increasingly used for organic pollutant degradation due to their high efficiency and environmental benignity relative to many other advanced oxidation processes. In the EF process, H2O2 and ferrous ions (Fe2+) are electrochemically generated in a controlled manner to yield hydroxyl radicals (HO⋅), and the process can be readily integrated with photocatalytic processes for sustainable operation. Of particular interest are the heterogeneous EF processes, which allow catalyst recycling and minimize the production of iron sludge wastes.

elements.content: Fe-containing carbon materials are commonly used for heterogeneous EF processes. A series of iron–carbon hybrid materials, including Fe@Fe2O3/carbon nanotubes, Fe3O4@Fe2O3/activated carbon aerogels (ACAs), FeO x /ACA, Fe2O3/carbon aerogels, and CoFe-layered double hydroxide (LDH)/carbon felts, have been prepared by immobilizing iron oxides on various carbonaceous materials. Despite the good bifunctional EF catalytic activity of these materials, they mostly suffer from poor long-term stability due to metal leaching or agglomeration of metal particles. A more beneficial strategy is to incorporate and disperse the Fe-containing nanoparticles into a porous carbon matrix. Nitrogen (N) doping is also usually applied to further improve the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity for H2O2 generation. Such composites (e.g., FeCuC aerogel and Fe3O4-NP@carbon nanofiber) generally show enhanced EF activity and mechanical stability, but metal leaching remains a key challenge to be addressed.

elements.content: Recently, metal–organic framework (MOF)-derived porous carbon materials have attracted intensive interest for catalysis applications. Such materials can well inherit the large surface area and good tailorability of MOFs and show good electric conductivity. To date, several metal/carbon materials have been prepared from MOFs, including BMZIF-20, ZIF-8, and ZIF-67, and their good oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activities have been demonstrated. However, these applications exclusively target on the ORR in the four-electron pathway.
elements.clean_text: Recently, metal-organic framework (MOF)-derived porous carbon materials have attracted intensive interest for catalysis applications. Such materials can well inherit the large surface area and good tailorability of MOFs and show good electric conductivity. To date, several metal/carbon materials have been prepared from MOFs, including BMZIF-20, ZIF-8, and ZIF-67, and their good oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activities have been demonstrated. However, these applications exclusively target on the ORR in the four-electron pathway.

elements.content: In this study, we fabricated a mesoporous N-doped carbon composite (Fe2O3/N–C) from Fe-based MOFs and examined its feasibility as a heterogeneous catalyst for EF processes. MIL-100­(Fe), a porous MOF with Fe­(III) octahedra, was selected as the precursor for catalyst fabrication, and polyaniline (PANI) was added for N doping. These precursors were carbonized through one-step pyrolysis at a relatively low temperature (550 °C) to obtain the Fe2O3/N–C. The EF performance of the material for degradation of Bisphenol A (BPA), a typical endocrine disruptor in the environment, was evaluated. To validate its universality for pollutant degradation, the removal of several other recalcitrant pollutants, including sulfanilamide (SA), Rhodamine B (RhB), and 4-chlorophenol (4-CP), was also examined. Lastly, the chemical stability of the catalyst was evaluated by examining the morphological and compositional changes and iron leaching during the reaction, and the BPA degradation rates in four cycles of repeated use. The contributions of heterogeneous and homogeneous EF reactions to pollutant degradation were also analyzed.

elements.content: Iron powder, hydrofluoric acid (HF), nitric acid (HNO3), aniline, and ammonium persulfate ((NH4)2S2O8) were purchased from Sinopharm. BPA, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (H3BTC), ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), terephthalic acid (H2BDC) and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. All chemicals and reagents were of analytical grade and were used without further purification unless otherwise specified. All solutions were prepared using deionized (DI) water (18.2 MΩ/cm).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents and Chemicals

Iron powder, hydrofluoric acid (HF), nitric acid (HNO3), aniline, and ammonium persulfate ((NH4)2S2O8) were purchased from Sinopharm. BPA, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (H3BTC), ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3⋅6H2O), terephthalic acid (H2BDC) and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. All chemicals and reagents were of analytical grade and were used without further purification unless otherwise specified. All solutions were prepared using deionized (DI) water (18.2 MΩ/cm).

elements.content: MIL-100­(Fe) was synthesized according to a previous report. Specifically, iron powder (266.0 mg), 1,3,5-H3BTC (668.5 mg), HF (40 wt %, 424 μL), HNO3 (65 wt %, 198 μL), and DI water (23.5 mL) were mixed in a Teflon liner. After full stirring, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and held at 150 °C for 24 h. After cooling down to room temperature and centrifugation, the products were soaked in hot water (80 °C) for 3 h to remove residual H3BTC and unreacted ions. MIL-53 (Fe) was fabricated by following a similar procedure with a slight modification: FeCl3·6H2O (0.674 g), H2BDC (0.415 g), and DMF (56 mL) were mixed in a Teflon liner, fully stirred, transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, and heated at 170 °C for 15 h. The samples were cooled down to room temperature, separated by centrifugation, and washed with DMF and ethanol to remove unreacted ions. After centrifugation, the harvested solids were vacuum dried at 60 °C overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of MIL-100 (Fe) and MIL-53 (Fe)

MIL-100(Fe) was synthesized according to a previous report. Specifically, iron powder (266.0 mg), 1,3,5-H3BTC (668.5 mg), HF (40 wt %, 424 μL), HNO3 (65 wt %, 198 μL), and DI water (23.5 mL) were mixed in a Teflon liner. After full stirring, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and held at 150 °C for 24 h. After cooling down to room temperature and centrifugation, the products were soaked in hot water (80 °C) for 3 h to remove residual H3BTC and unreacted ions. MIL-53 (Fe) was fabricated by following a similar procedure with a slight modification: FeCl3⋅6H2O (0.674 g), H2BDC (0.415 g), and DMF (56 mL) were mixed in a Teflon liner, fully stirred, transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, and heated at 170 °C for 15 h. The samples were cooled down to room temperature, separated by centrifugation, and washed with DMF and ethanol to remove unreacted ions. After centrifugation, the harvested solids were vacuum dried at 60 °C overnight.

elements.content: PANI was synthesized by following a previously reported method with a minor modification. The (NH4)2S2O8 solution was prepared by dissolving 4.998 g of (NH4)2S2O8 in 1 M HCl solution and then adding it dropwise into 0.02 M aniline hydrochloric acid solution under vigorous stirring. After 6 h of reaction at 4 °C, the sample was collected by suction filtration, washed with DI water and ethanol several times, and finally dried at 60 °C overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of PANI

PANI was synthesized by following a previously reported method with a minor modification. The (NH4)2S2O8 solution was prepared by dissolving 4.998 g of (NH4)2S2O8 in 1 M HCl solution and then adding it dropwise into 0.02 M aniline hydrochloric acid solution under vigorous stirring. After 6 h of reaction at 4 °C, the sample was collected by suction filtration, washed with DI water and ethanol several times, and finally dried at 60 °C overnight.

elements.content: A mixture of 2 g of MIL-100­(Fe) and 1 g of PANI was carbonized in an N2 atmosphere at 3 °C/min increments until the temperature reached 550 °C, held for 3 h, and then cooled down to room temperature to obtain a Fe2O3/N–C composite. For comparison, Fe2O3/N–C composites with different MIL-100­(Fe) to PANI mass ratios (1:4, 1:2: 1:1, and 2:1) were also fabricated. The same procedures were adopted for Fe2O3/C and N–C fabrication, except for using solely MIL-100­(Fe) or PANI as the precursor. To optimize the precursor, the Fe2O3/N–C (MIL-53) composite was also fabricated using MIL-53­(Fe) as an alternative Fe-based MOF. MIL-53­(Fe) was synthesized according to a previous report. To prepare the electrode, 10 mg of catalyst was dispersed in 950 μL of isopropanol and 50 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt %). After sonication for 30 min, the ink solution was uniformly coated onto a carbon paper (surface area 6.0 cm2). For comparison, another composite of Fe2O3/N–C (MIL-53) was prepared from the MIL-53 (Fe) precursor by following the same fabrication procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Fe2O3/N-C Cathode

A mixture of 2 g of MIL-100(Fe) and 1 g of PANI was carbonized in an N2 atmosphere at 3 °C/min increments until the temperature reached 550 °C, held for 3 h, and then cooled down to room temperature to obtain a Fe2O3/N-C composite. For comparison, Fe2O3/N-C composites with different MIL-100(Fe) to PANI mass ratios (1:4, 1:2: 1:1, and 2:1) were also fabricated. The same procedures were adopted for Fe2O3/C and N-C fabrication, except for using solely MIL-100(Fe) or PANI as the precursor. To optimize the precursor, the Fe2O3/N-C (MIL-53) composite was also fabricated using MIL-53(Fe) as an alternative Fe-based MOF. MIL-53(Fe) was synthesized according to a previous report. To prepare the electrode, 10 mg of catalyst was dispersed in 950 μL of isopropanol and 50 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt %). After sonication for 30 min, the ink solution was uniformly coated onto a carbon paper (surface area 6.0 cm2). For comparison, another composite of Fe2O3/N-C (MIL-53) was prepared from the MIL-53 (Fe) precursor by following the same fabrication procedures.

elements.content: The material morphology was observed using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-6700F) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN). The specific surface areas and pore sizes were measured by following the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method using a Builder 4200 instrument (Tristar II 3020M). The crystal structure was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using filtered Cu Kα radiation (α = 1.54178 Å) (Bruker D8 diffractometer). The chemical compositions and valence states of constituent elements were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi). To examine the chemical stability of the material, after 2 h of EF reaction, the catalyst was peeled off from the carbon paper using ethanol. After centrifugation and drying, the sample was also subjected to energy-dispersive spectra (EDS) and XRD analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Physicochemical Characterization

The material morphology was observed using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-6700F) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN). The specific surface areas and pore sizes were measured by following the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method using a Builder 4200 instrument (Tristar II 3020M). The crystal structure was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using filtered Cu Kα radiation (α = 1.54178 Å) (Bruker D8 diffractometer). The chemical compositions and valence states of constituent elements were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi). To examine the chemical stability of the material, after 2 h of EF reaction, the catalyst was peeled off from the carbon paper using ethanol. After centrifugation and drying, the sample was also subjected to energy-dispersive spectra (EDS) and XRD analysis.

elements.content: Electrochemical characterization was performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660D) with a three-electrode configuration. A Pt wire and an Ag/AgCl electrode served as the anode and reference electrode, respectively. The recorded potentials in this study were converted to those corresponding to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) using the equation E vs RHE = E vs Ag / AgCl + 0.059 × pH + 0.197 The catalyst-modified carbon paper was used as the working electrode. The initial pH of the Na2SO4 electrolyte (0.05 M) was adjusted to 3.0 using 1 M H2SO4 or NaOH. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was recorded in an O2-saturated electrolyte at a scan rate of 50 mV/s. Material conductivity was determined by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in a 0.05 M Na2SO4 electrolyte at the open-circuit potential, with the frequency ranging from 100 to 1 × 106 Hz at an amplitude of 5 mV. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed over a glassy carbon disk electrode. Rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurement was performed at rotation rates of 100–2500 rpm with a sweep rate of 5 mV/s. The electron transfer number (n) of Fe2O3/N–C for the ORR was calculated according to the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equations 1 J = 1 J K + 1 J L = 1 J K + 1 B ω 1 / 2 B = 0.2 n F C O 2 ( D O 2 ) 2 / 3 υ 1 / 6 where J is the measured current density, J K and J L are the kinetic and diffusion-limited current density, respectively, ω is the electrode rotation rate (in rpm), F is the Faraday constant (96 485 C/mol), CO2 is the bulk concentration of O2 (1.3 × 10–3 M), D O2 is the O2 diffusion coefficient (1.9 × 10–5 cm2/s) in acidic solution, and ν is the kinetic viscosity of the electrolyte (1.0 × 10–2 cm2/s).

elements.content: The catalytic degradation of BPA by Fe2O3/N–C was examined in a glass electrochemical cell with the same electrolyte as above. The initial BPA concentration was 10 mg/L. Prior to the EF reaction, the solution was bubbled with compressed air (0.4 L/min) for 30 min for O2 saturation. Then, a poised cathode potential of −0.34 V was applied, and the solution was continuously stirred. Samples were collected at given time intervals and immediately added to excess isopropyl alcohol to cease the reaction. The BPA concentration was analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Shimadzu LC-16) with an Eclipse XDB-C18 column (5 μm, Agilent) and an SPD-16 detector at a wavelength of 273 nm. The mobile phase was a mixture of acetonitrile and formic acid solution (0.1 wt %) at 70:30 (v/v) ratio and a flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. The degradation kinetics of BPA in the EF process with different cathodes was analyzed using the pseudo-first-order kinetic equation: ln ( C 0 C ) = kt where k is the apparent reaction constant (min–1), and C 0 and C are the BPA concentrations at the beginning of the reaction and at time t, respectively.

The degradation kinetics of BPA in the EF process with different cathodes was analyzed using the pseudo-first-order kinetic equation: 4    ln  (     C   0     C   )  = kt   where k is the apparent reaction constant (min-1), and C 0 and C are the BPA concentrations at the beginning of the reaction and at time t, respectively.

elements.content: The current efficiency for H2O2 generation was calculated using the equation C E ( % ) = 2 F n H 2 O 2 ∫ 0 t I dt × 100 % where I is the instantaneous current (A), nH2O2 is the generated H2O2 (moles), and t is the test time (s).

elements.content: To identify the intermediate products formed during BPA degradation, 50 mL of BPA solution (initial concentration 50 mg/L) was collected after 2.5 h of reaction, immediately concentrated, and extracted by a C18 column. Then, the concentrated samples were analyzed using an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph (GC) coupled with an Agilent 5975C mass spectrometer (MS) with 2.5 mL methanol as the eluant. The generated H2O2 in the electrolyte was measured by the titanium­(IV) spectrophotometric method. The total organic carbon (TOC) was determined using a TOC analyzer (Multi N/C 2100, Analytik Jena AG).

elements.content: The amount of leached Fe from the catalyst during the reaction was measured by o-phenanthroline colorimetric method. The total amount of iron on the electrodes before and after use was also measured to verify Fe leaching. The catalyst-loaded electrodes were immersed in 10 mL of hydrochloric acid (6 M) for 12 h to sufficiently solubilize the Fe, and then the Fe content in the solution was analyzed.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Stability and Reaction Mechanism Study

The amount of leached Fe from the catalyst during the reaction was measured by o-phenanthroline colorimetric method. The total amount of iron on the electrodes before and after use was also measured to verify Fe leaching. The catalyst-loaded electrodes were immersed in 10 mL of hydrochloric acid (6 M) for 12 h to sufficiently solubilize the Fe, and then the Fe content in the solution was analyzed.

elements.content: Based on the leached amount of Fe ions, the contribution of the homogeneous EF process to BPA degradation was estimated. To eliminate the contribution of homogenous EF, an electrode-free control was used. Ferric ions (at equivalent amount to the leached Fe ions in the Fe2O3/N–C reaction system) and H2O2 (based on its theoretical yield in the Fe2O3/N–C system) were spiked into the electrolyte. The theoretical H2O2 concentration was calculated based on , assuming 100% current efficiency for H2O2 generation. To better mimic the H2O2 generation scenario in the Fe2O3/N–C system, another control group with N–C as the cathode and Fe2+ as the homogeneous catalyst was also tested. In addition, the electro-regeneration of soluble Fe3+ was evaluated by inserting a plain carbon paper electrode (as an Fe-free cathode) in an N2-saturated electrolyte.

elements.content: The morphology and composition of Fe2O3/N–C differed significantly from those of the MOF precursor. The MIL-100­(Fe) crystals exhibit an octahedral structure and a relatively large size (around 10 μm) (Figure S1). In contrast, Fe2O3/N–C shows a small particle size of around 200 nm (a), a high BET surface area (267.6 m2/g) (Table S1), and a mesoporous structure (average pore diameter 7.08 nm) (Figure S2a). According to the EDS elemental mapping, the N, Fe, and O elements were evenly dispersed in the carbon matrix (b–d). The TEM images (e) confirm that abundant dark-colored nanoparticles were embedded in a carbon matrix, with the nanoparticle lattice fringe spacing (0.297 and 0.492 nm) corresponding to the (220) and (111) planes of Fe2O3 crystals (f). Consistently, the XRD spectrum () shows a series of characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe2O3 corresponding to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) planes of maghemite (PDF#39-1346). These results confirm the formation and even dispersion of Fe2O3 nanoparticles in the carbon matrix. The crystal structure of the Fe2O3 nanoparticles remained unchanged after 2 h of reaction (Figure S3a).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Morphology and Structure of Fe2O3/N-C

The morphology and composition of Fe2O3/N-C differed significantly from those of the MOF precursor. The MIL-100(Fe) crystals exhibit an octahedral structure and a relatively large size (around 10 μm) (Figure S1). In contrast, Fe2O3/N-C shows a small particle size of around 200 nm (a), a high BET surface area (267.6 m2/g) (Table S1), and a mesoporous structure (average pore diameter 7.08 nm) (Figure S2a). According to the EDS elemental mapping, the N, Fe, and O elements were evenly dispersed in the carbon matrix (b-d). The TEM images (e) confirm that abundant dark-colored nanoparticles were embedded in a carbon matrix, with the nanoparticle lattice fringe spacing (0.297 and 0.492 nm) corresponding to the (220) and (111) planes of Fe2O3 crystals (f). Consistently, the XRD spectrum () shows a series of characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe2O3 corresponding to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) planes of maghemite (PDF#39-1346). These results confirm the formation and even dispersion of Fe2O3 nanoparticles in the carbon matrix. The crystal structure of the Fe2O3 nanoparticles remained unchanged after 2 h of reaction (Figure S3a).

elements.content: The chemical composition and surface electronic states of Fe2O3/N–C were further analyzed by XPS (). The atomic ratios of C, N, Fe, and O elements were 85.42, 7.54, 1.31, and 5.73%, respectively (Table S1). The high-resolution C 1s XPS spectrum could be deconvoluted into two main peaks at 284.6 eV (65.6%) and 285.6 eV (17.1%), which are assigned for C–C and C–N, respectively (a). The other weak peaks at 286.8 and 288.9 eV are ascribed to C–O and O–CO, respectively. Consistently, covalently bonded N functional groups, including pyridinic-N (398.6 eV), graphitic-N (401.1 eV), and pyrrolic-N (400.3 eV), were identified by the N 1s XPS spectrum (b). The Fe 2p spectra show several characteristic peaks of Fe2O3 (c): the peaks at 710.7 and 712.8 eV are attributed to the binding energy of Fe 2p3/2 orbitals; the 724.6 eV peak corresponds to the 2p1/2 orbitals of Fe3+; the satellite peaks at 718.0 and 729.9 eV are, respectively, assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2. The lattice O in the Fe2O3 crystal (530.2 eV) is identified by the O 1s XPS spectrum (d). The intense signals of O in lattice Fe–O–H and hydroxyl (−OH) groups (shown by the peak at 531.7 eV) indicate the presence of abundant surface-bound −OH groups. The weak peak at 553.4 eV can be assigned to the O in adsorbed H2O. These results confirm that the Fe2O3/N–C material contained abundant pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, and hydroxyl functional groups.

elements.content: The CV curve of the Fe2O3/N–C catalyst in an O2-saturated solution shows a distinct oxygen reduction peak at 0.42 V (which is missing in an N2-saturated solution) (a), indicating good ORR activity. In addition, the LSV curve measured by a rotating disk electrode shows a typical peak plateau (between −0.47 and −0.37 V) corresponding to H2O2 generation (b). The K–L plots measured at various electrode potentials show good linearity (c), suggesting a diffusion-controlled ORR process. The calculated average electron transfer number was 2.86, indicating the predominance of the two-electron ORR pathway. Such high selectivity of the catalyst might be associated with the introduced pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N groups, which could enhance electronic transmission and oxygen adsorption to favor H2O2 generation.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Properties

The CV curve of the Fe2O3/N-C catalyst in an O2-saturated solution shows a distinct oxygen reduction peak at 0.42 V (which is missing in an N2-saturated solution) (a), indicating good ORR activity. In addition, the LSV curve measured by a rotating disk electrode shows a typical peak plateau (between -0.47 and -0.37 V) corresponding to H2O2 generation (b). The K-L plots measured at various electrode potentials show good linearity (c), suggesting a diffusion-controlled ORR process. The calculated average electron transfer number was 2.86, indicating the predominance of the two-electron ORR pathway. Such high selectivity of the catalyst might be associated with the introduced pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N groups, which could enhance electronic transmission and oxygen adsorption to favor H2O2 generation.

elements.content: The high ORR selectivity of Fe2O3/N–C was verified by the fast H2O2 generation (a). The accumulative H2O2 concentration showed a rapid increase initially and then slowed down due to increased H2O2 activation, while no H2O2 consumption was found in the Fe2O3-free N–C electrode system. H2O2 activation by Fe2O3/N–C resulted in the generation of •OH (b). In comparison, little H2O2 generation was shown by Fe2O3/C (N-free control) despite its smaller charge transfer resistance than the other two materials (d), indicating the predominance of the four-electron ORR pathway in Fe2O3/C. Consistently, a much higher current efficiency for H2O2 production was achieved by N-doped materials (51.54% for Fe2O3/N–C and 43.30% for N–C) over Fe2O3/C (2.7%) (Figure S4). These results confirm that the doped-N species function as active sites for H2O2 electrogeneration, although their presence also increases the electrical resistance due to decreased C-sp2 hybridization.

elements.content: Fe2O3/N–C obviously outperformed Fe2O3/N–C­(MIL-53) in H2O2 generation and pollutant degradation rates (Figure S7), indicating that MIL-100­(Fe) is a more suitable MOF precursor than MIL-53­(Fe). XRD analysis shows that both materials contain predominantly Fe2O3 crystals (, S3b), indicating little difference in the Fe species. Thus, the inferior performance of Fe2O3/N–C­(MIL-53) should be mainly associated with its lower content of the C–N bond and smaller specific surface area (Table S1). The XPS spectra reveal slightly less content of N element in Fe2O3/N–C­(MIL-53) than in Fe2O3/N–C. In addition, the C 1s XPS spectra show a lower proportion of the C–N bond (the active sites for oxygen adsorption) in Fe2O3/N–C­(MIL-53) (13.5 vs 17.1% in Fe2O3/N–C) (Figure S8). These results further verify the important role of C–N species in selective H2O2 generation.

elements.content: The catalytic performance of EF catalysts depends strongly on the applied potential, solution pH, and catalyst composition. In the Fe2O3/N–C system, BPA removal within 120 min increased from 86.4% at an applied potential of −0.14 V to 100% at −0.34 V (Figure S10b) due to increased Fe­(II) regeneration. However, further lowering the potential to −0.54 V decreased the BPA removal to 49.1%, likely due to the suppressed H2O2 production (Figure S11a) by competitive reactions such as H2 evolution and one-electron and/or four-electron ORR. Notably, at cathode potential of −0.34 V, the heterogeneous EF system showed a current density of only 1.0 mA/cm2, much lower than those in previous heterogeneous EF systems ().
elements.clean_text:
Influences of pH, Voltage, and Catalyst Composition

The catalytic performance of EF catalysts depends strongly on the applied potential, solution pH, and catalyst composition. In the Fe2O3/N-C system, BPA removal within 120 min increased from 86.4% at an applied potential of -0.14 V to 100% at -0.34 V (Figure S10b) due to increased Fe(II) regeneration. However, further lowering the potential to -0.54 V decreased the BPA removal to 49.1%, likely due to the suppressed H2O2 production (Figure S11a) by competitive reactions such as H2 evolution and one-electron and/or four-electron ORR. Notably, at cathode potential of -0.34 V, the heterogeneous EF system showed a current density of only 1.0 mA/cm2, much lower than those in previous heterogeneous EF systems ().

The solution pH also significantly affects the degradation kinetics. Increasing the pH to 5.0 and above severely suppressed BPA degradation (Figure S10c), likely attributed to a combined effect of decreased H2O2 production and precipitation of leached Fe ions. Finally, the catalysts fabricated with different mass ratios of MIL-100­(Fe) and PANI precursors also showed different catalytic performances (Figure S10d). The catalyst fabricated with MIL-100­(Fe)/PANI at a mass ratio of 2:1 showed the highest activity (Figure S11b), likely due to its well-balanced functions for H2O2 generation and activation.

elements.content: The used Fe2O3/N–C electrode (b) showed similar morphology and structure as the pristine one (a). According to the EDS analysis and Fe content assay, the Fe content in the catalyst decreased only slightly after the reaction (c,d, S12). Consistently, Fe leaching from the catalysts was very slow, and the Fe ion concentration in the solution reached only 0.52 mg/L after 120 min of reaction (a). The Fe leaching ratio (relative to the Fe content in the catalyst) was only 0.42%, less than those in other heterogeneous EF systems (0.75–5.37% of total metal ion leaching) (). Such low leaching of Fe may be associated with the well-confined nanoparticles in the carbon matrix and a high content of surface −OH groups that bind strongly with the dissolved Fe2+.
elements.clean_text:
Fe Leaching and Catalyst Stability

The used Fe2O3/N-C electrode (b) showed similar morphology and structure as the pristine one (a). According to the EDS analysis and Fe content assay, the Fe content in the catalyst decreased only slightly after the reaction (c,d, S12). Consistently, Fe leaching from the catalysts was very slow, and the Fe ion concentration in the solution reached only 0.52 mg/L after 120 min of reaction (a). The Fe leaching ratio (relative to the Fe content in the catalyst) was only 0.42%, less than those in other heterogeneous EF systems (0.75-5.37% of total metal ion leaching) (). Such low leaching of Fe may be associated with the well-confined nanoparticles in the carbon matrix and a high content of surface -OH groups that bind strongly with the dissolved Fe2+.

elements.content: Little Fe leaching means a small contribution of homogeneous EF to the reaction system. As expected, the homogeneous EF system, with spiked Fe2+ and H2O2 (at the same levels as those in the Fe2O3/N–C system, i.e., 0.52 mg/L Fe2+ and 1.97 mM H2O2), showed only 33.9% BPA removal within 2 h. Another control group of homogeneous EF with an N–C cathode and spiked Fe2+ also showed much lower BPA removal than the Fe2O3/N–C system (b). The low leaching of Fe also implies the high chemical stability of the Fe2O3/N–C catalyst for repeated use. After four test cycles, Fe2O3/N–C retained 98% catalytic activity for BPA degradation (), implying the high stability of this catalyst to favor sustained EF processes for degradation of various types of organic pollution.

elements.content: A novel Fe2O3/N–C catalyst was fabricated through one-step carbonization of MIL-100­(Fe) and PANI. The introduction of pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N functional groups significantly improved the H2O2 electroproduction due to a favorable two-electron ORR pathway. Meanwhile, the uniformly dispersed Fe2O3 nanoparticles in the mesoporous carbon matrix enabled the efficient activation of H2O2 for •OH generation. The Fe2O3/N–C cathode shows low Fe leaching and exhibits high EF catalytic activity for organic pollutant degradation and good stability for repeated use. Given the facile fabrication and good performance of the Fe2O3/N–C composite, it holds great potential for practical wastewater treatment and environmental remediation applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A novel Fe2O3/N-C catalyst was fabricated through one-step carbonization of MIL-100(Fe) and PANI. The introduction of pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N functional groups significantly improved the H2O2 electroproduction due to a favorable two-electron ORR pathway. Meanwhile, the uniformly dispersed Fe2O3 nanoparticles in the mesoporous carbon matrix enabled the efficient activation of H2O2 for ⋅OH generation. The Fe2O3/N-C cathode shows low Fe leaching and exhibits high EF catalytic activity for organic pollutant degradation and good stability for repeated use. Given the facile fabrication and good performance of the Fe2O3/N-C composite, it holds great potential for practical wastewater treatment and environmental remediation applications.

cln_elements.content:
MIL-100­(Fe) was synthesized according to a previous report. Specifically, iron powder (266.0 mg), 1,3,5-H3BTC (668.5 mg), HF (40 wt %, 424 μL), HNO3 (65 wt %, 198 μL), and DI water (23.5 mL) were mixed in a Teflon liner. After full stirring, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and held at 150 °C for 24 h. After cooling down to room temperature and centrifugation, the products were soaked in hot water (80 °C) for 3 h to remove residual H3BTC and unreacted ions. MIL-53 (Fe) was fabricated by following a similar procedure with a slight modification: FeCl3·6H2O (0.674 g), H2BDC (0.415 g), and DMF (56 mL) were mixed in a Teflon liner, fully stirred, transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, and heated at 170 °C for 15 h. The samples were cooled down to room temperature, separated by centrifugation, and washed with DMF and ethanol to remove unreacted ions. After centrifugation, the harvested solids were vacuum dried at 60 °C overnight.

Preparation of PANI

PANI was synthesized by following a previously reported method with a minor modification. The (NH4)2S2O8 solution was prepared by dissolving 4.998 g of (NH4)2S2O8 in 1 M HCl solution and then adding it dropwise into 0.02 M aniline hydrochloric acid solution under vigorous stirring. After 6 h of reaction at 4 °C, the sample was collected by suction filtration, washed with DI water and ethanol several times, and finally dried at 60 °C overnight.

Preparation of the Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/N–C Cathode

A mixture of 2 g of MIL-100­(Fe) and 1 g of PANI was carbonized in an N2 atmosphere at 3 °C/min increments until the temperature reached 550 °C, held for 3 h, and then cooled down to room temperature to obtain a Fe2O3/N–C composite. For comparison, Fe2O3/N–C composites with different MIL-100­(Fe) to PANI mass ratios (1:4, 1:2: 1:1, and 2:1) were also fabricated. The same procedures were adopted for Fe2O3/C and N–C fabrication, except for using solely MIL-100­(Fe) or PANI as the precursor. To optimize the precursor, the Fe2O3/N–C (MIL-53) composite was also fabricated using MIL-53­(Fe) as an alternative Fe-based MOF. MIL-53­(Fe) was synthesized according to a previous report. To prepare the electrode, 10 mg of catalyst was dispersed in 950 μL of isopropanol and 50 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt %). After sonication for 30 min, the ink solution was uniformly coated onto a carbon paper (surface area 6.0 cm2). For comparison, another composite of Fe2O3/N–C (MIL-53) was prepared from the MIL-53 (Fe) precursor by following the same fabrication procedures.

cln_elements.content:
The morphology and composition of Fe2O3/N–C differed significantly from those of the MOF precursor. The MIL-100­(Fe) crystals exhibit an octahedral structure and a relatively large size (around 10 μm) (Figure S1). In contrast, Fe2O3/N–C shows a small particle size of around 200 nm (a), a high BET surface area (267.6 m2/g) (Table S1), and a mesoporous structure (average pore diameter 7.08 nm) (Figure S2a). According to the EDS elemental mapping, the N, Fe, and O elements were evenly dispersed in the carbon matrix (b–d). The TEM images (e) confirm that abundant dark-colored nanoparticles were embedded in a carbon matrix, with the nanoparticle lattice fringe spacing (0.297 and 0.492 nm) corresponding to the (220) and (111) planes of Fe2O3 crystals (f). Consistently, the XRD spectrum () shows a series of characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe2O3 corresponding to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) planes of maghemite (PDF#39-1346). These results confirm the formation and even dispersion of Fe2O3 nanoparticles in the carbon matrix. The crystal structure of the Fe2O3 nanoparticles remained unchanged after 2 h of reaction (Figure S3a).

Electrochemical Properties

The CV curve of the Fe2O3/N–C catalyst in an O2-saturated solution shows a distinct oxygen reduction peak at 0.42 V (which is missing in an N2-saturated solution) (a), indicating good ORR activity. In addition, the LSV curve measured by a rotating disk electrode shows a typical peak plateau (between −0.47 and −0.37 V) corresponding to H2O2 generation (b). The K–L plots measured at various electrode potentials show good linearity (c), suggesting a diffusion-controlled ORR process. The calculated average electron transfer number was 2.86, indicating the predominance of the two-electron ORR pathway. Such high selectivity of the catalyst might be associated with the introduced pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N groups, which could enhance electronic transmission and oxygen adsorption to favor H2O2 generation.

Pollutant Degradation Performance

At a cathode potential of −0.34 V, the Fe2O3/N–C catalyst achieved 100% BPA removal within 120 min (a). BPA degradation was confirmed by the considerable removal of TOC (b) and the formation of p-isopropenyl phenol and 1,3,5-bis­(1,1-dimethyl­(ethyl)) as degradation intermediates (Figures S5 and S6). Only 7.7% of BPA removal was ascribed to electrosorption (a).

Influences of pH, Voltage, and Catalyst Composition

The catalytic performance of EF catalysts depends strongly on the applied potential, solution pH, and catalyst composition. In the Fe2O3/N–C system, BPA removal within 120 min increased from 86.4% at an applied potential of −0.14 V to 100% at −0.34 V (Figure S10b) due to increased Fe­(II) regeneration. However, further lowering the potential to −0.54 V decreased the BPA removal to 49.1%, likely due to the suppressed H2O2 production (Figure S11a) by competitive reactions such as H2 evolution and one-electron and/or four-electron ORR. Notably, at cathode potential of −0.34 V, the heterogeneous EF system showed a current density of only 1.0 mA/cm2, much lower than those in previous heterogeneous EF systems ().

Fe Leaching and Catalyst Stability

The used Fe2O3/N–C electrode (b) showed similar morphology and structure as the pristine one (a). According to the EDS analysis and Fe content assay, the Fe content in the catalyst decreased only slightly after the reaction (c,d, S12). Consistently, Fe leaching from the catalysts was very slow, and the Fe ion concentration in the solution reached only 0.52 mg/L after 120 min of reaction (a). The Fe leaching ratio (relative to the Fe content in the catalyst) was only 0.42%, less than those in other heterogeneous EF systems (0.75–5.37% of total metal ion leaching) (). Such low leaching of Fe may be associated with the well-confined nanoparticles in the carbon matrix and a high content of surface −OH groups that bind strongly with the dissolved Fe2+.
